articles.headline: Fast-Growing Endowments, Without the Ivy
articles.snippet: The best-performing college endowments have less than $1 billion — places like Abilene Christian and Spalding University, not giants like Yale.
articles.abstract: The best-performing college endowments have less than $1 billion — places like Abilene Christian and Spalding University, not giants like Yale.
articles.lead_paragraph: Move over, Yale.

articles.headline: Standing Up for the Rights of New Fathers
articles.snippet: More workers are filing legal actions against their employers to gain paid parental leave for the birth of a child, experts say.
articles.abstract: More workers are filing legal actions against their employers to gain paid parental leave for the birth of a child, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Josh Levs, father of a new baby girl, emerged from his sleep-deprived stupor last month to take a stand: He is challenging his employer’s parental leave policy on the grounds that it discriminates against biological dads.

articles.headline: The Olympics of the Future
articles.snippet: Japan, finally emerging from a long economic downturn, hopes to re-establish itself as a technological powerhouse when Tokyo hosts the 2020 Games.
articles.abstract: Japan, finally emerging from a long economic downturn, hopes to re-establish itself as a technological powerhouse when Tokyo hosts the 2020 Games.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — From the moment in September when Tokyo won the tight race to host the 2020 Summer Olympics, locals have been unleashing ideas — some far-fetched, others tantalizingly imaginable — of what the city will offer the more than 10 million spectators expected to attend the Games.

articles.headline: Right Wing’s Surge in Europe Has the Establishment Rattled
articles.snippet: All over Europe, established political forces are losing ground to grass-roots insurgents fired by resentment against a governing class many see as out of touch.
articles.abstract: All over Europe, established political forces are losing ground to grass-roots insurgents fired by resentment against a governing class many see as out of touch.
articles.lead_paragraph: HVIDOVRE, Denmark — As right-wing populists surge across Europe, rattling established political parties with their hostility toward immigration, austerity and the European Union, Mikkel Dencker of the Danish People’s Party has found yet another cause to stir public anger: pork meatballs missing from kindergartens.

articles.headline: As Tensions Fall in Iran, So Do Costs of Gasoline
articles.snippet: Energy experts say prices may fall further if talks between the United States and Iran bear fruit.
articles.abstract: Energy experts say prices may fall further if talks between the United States and Iran bear fruit.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Gasoline prices are tumbling just in time for the holiday shopping season to begin.

articles.headline: Bloomberg News Is Said to Curb Articles That Might Anger China
articles.snippet: Employees said Bloomberg News chose not to publish investigative articles about China’s leadership because of worries that it would be evicted from the country.
articles.abstract: Employees said Bloomberg News chose not to publish investigative articles about China’s leadership because of worries that it would be evicted from the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The decision came in an early evening call to four journalists huddled in a Hong Kong conference room. On the line 12 time zones away in New York was their boss, Matthew Winkler, the longtime editor in chief of Bloomberg News. And they were frustrated by what he was telling them.

articles.headline: Executions Stall as States Seek Different Drugs
articles.snippet: Facing increasing pressure and scrutiny from death penalty opponents, the makers of several drugs used in lethal injections have ceased production or required that they not be used in executions.
articles.abstract: Facing increasing pressure and scrutiny from death penalty opponents, the makers of several drugs used in lethal injections have ceased production or required that they not be used in executions.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Florida ran out of its primary lethal-injection drug last month and relied on a new drug that no state had ever used for an execution. At Ohio’s next scheduled execution, the state is planning to use a two-drug combination for the first time. Last month in Texas, Michael Yowell became that state’s first inmate executed using a drug made by a lightly regulated pharmacy that usually produces customized medications for individual patients.

articles.headline: Talks With Iran Fail to Produce a Nuclear Agreement
articles.snippet: Puncturing days of feverish anticipation, marathon talks were stymied not only by divisions between Iran and major powers, but also by fissures within the group negotiating with Iran.
articles.abstract: Puncturing days of feverish anticipation, marathon talks were stymied not only by divisions between Iran and major powers, but also by fissures within the group negotiating with Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Marathon talks between major powers and Iran failed on Sunday to produce a deal to freeze its nuclear program, puncturing days of feverish anticipation and underscoring how hard it will be to forge a lasting solution to Iran’s nuclear ambitions.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: A Founder of Twitter Goes Long
articles.snippet: Evan Williams, who helped create companies like Blogger and Twitter, is setting his sights on longer-form writing with a new blogging platform, Medium.
articles.abstract: Evan Williams, who helped create companies like Blogger and Twitter, is setting his sights on longer-form writing with a new blogging platform, Medium.
articles.lead_paragraph: Between downtown San Francisco and the new Twitter offices six city blocks to the west, things get sketchy. There is a strip club, a budget motel with weekly rates and, on the gentrified edge of this no-man’s land, the offices of Medium, the new venture of Evan Williams, one of Twitter’s co-founders.

articles.headline: Earnings, but Without the Bad Stuff
articles.snippet: Managers of companies that have generated only losses, like Twitter, are happy to suggest metrics that they think are better suited for assessing their operations.
articles.abstract: Managers of companies that have generated only losses, like Twitter, are happy to suggest metrics that they think are better suited for assessing their operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter’s red-hot stock offering last week makes clear that, as in the first Internet bubble, investors will pay up for a company even if it hasn’t turned a profit.

articles.headline: Treasure Hunters of the Financial Crisis
articles.snippet: In 2008, a year when the global financial system was falling apart and markets panicked, these investors didn’t. How three big risks, taken by three firms, turned to gold.
articles.abstract: In 2008, a year when the global financial system was falling apart and markets panicked, these investors didn’t. How three big risks, taken by three firms, turned to gold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the global financial system was falling apart. Lehman Brothers had imploded. Banks had stopped lending. Foreclosure signs were as common as weeds on the front lawns of suburban homes.

articles.headline: New China Cities: Shoddy Homes, Broken Hope
articles.snippet: China’s government-led urbanization, meant to solve one problem, may be creating a new set of troubles that could plague Chinese cities for generations.
articles.abstract: China’s government-led urbanization, meant to solve one problem, may be creating a new set of troubles that could plague Chinese cities for generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUAMING, China — Three years ago, the Shanghai World Expo featured this newly built town as a model for how China would move from being a land of farms to a land of cities. In a dazzling pavilion visited by more than a million people, visitors learned how farmers were being given a new life through a fair-and-square deal that did not cost them anything.

articles.headline: Obama’s Portable Zone of Secrecy (Some Assembly Required)
articles.snippet: When the president travels and needs to handle sensitive information, he ducks into a security tent set up by aides to shield himself from secret cameras and listening devices.
articles.abstract: When the president travels and needs to handle sensitive information, he ducks into a security tent set up by aides to shield himself from secret cameras and listening devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama travels abroad, his staff packs briefing books, gifts for foreign leaders and something more closely associated with camping than diplomacy: a tent.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Conservative U.S. Catholics Feel Left Out of the Pope’s Embrace
articles.snippet: Conservative Catholics say Pope Francis’ recent comments about abortion and gay marriage are muddying doctrine to appeal to the broadest possible audience.
articles.abstract: Conservative Catholics say Pope Francis’ recent comments about abortion and gay marriage are muddying doctrine to appeal to the broadest possible audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: SMYRNA, Ga. — When Pope Francis was elected in March, Bridget Kurt received a small prayer card with his picture at her church and put it up on her refrigerator at home, next to pictures of her friends and her favorite saints.

articles.headline: Con Men Prey on Confusion Over Health Care Act
articles.snippet: State and federal authorities have reported a rising number of consumer complaints, ranging from deceptive sales practices to identity theft, linked to the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: State and federal authorities have reported a rising number of consumer complaints, ranging from deceptive sales practices to identity theft, linked to the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the list of problems plaguing President Obama’s health care law, add one more — fraud.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: As Washington Keeps Sinking, Governors Rise
articles.snippet: With Washington mired in gridlock, some state political leaders are showing they can still get things done.
articles.abstract: With Washington mired in gridlock, some state political leaders are showing they can still get things done.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Washington these days is the symbol of governmental failure, rocked by a shutdown, legislative paralysis and the disastrous debut of President Obama’s health care program. Public opinion of Mr. Obama and members of Congress is on a steady decline.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Vast Challenges for Philippines After Typhoon
articles.snippet: Typhoon Haiyan delivered a crippling blow to the country’s midsection and appeared to have brought a heavy loss of life to cities, towns and villages.
articles.abstract: Typhoon Haiyan delivered a crippling blow to the country’s midsection and appeared to have brought a heavy loss of life to cities, towns and villages.
articles.lead_paragraph: CEBU, Philippines — Three days after one of the most powerful storms ever to buffet the Philippines, the scale of the devastation and the desperation of the survivors were slowly coming into view.

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Take Up Challenges to Union Practices
articles.snippet: Two cases this term — involving neutrality agreements with employers and the requirement that home care workers pay fees to unions — could produce significant rulings.
articles.abstract: Two cases this term — involving neutrality agreements with employers and the requirement that home care workers pay fees to unions — could produce significant rulings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Labor leaders and businesses are closely watching a Supreme Court case to be argued this Wednesday that involves a popular strategy used by unions to successfully organize hundreds of thousands of workers.

articles.headline: Big Data’s Little Brother
articles.snippet: Start-ups are gathering data and analyzing it much faster than was possible even a couple of years ago, aiming to project economic trends from seemingly unconnected information.
articles.abstract: Start-ups are gathering data and analyzing it much faster than was possible even a couple of years ago, aiming to project economic trends from seemingly unconnected information.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — David Soloff is recruiting an army of “hyperdata” collectors.

articles.headline: BlackBerry’s Woes Draw Canada’s Contrarian Mogul Into Spotlight
articles.snippet: The saving of BlackBerry may represent a patriotic calling to V. Prem Watsa, But he is not used to dealing in as public an arena as the company does.
articles.abstract: The saving of BlackBerry may represent a patriotic calling to V. Prem Watsa, But he is not used to dealing in as public an arena as the company does.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout the first weekend of November, V. Prem Watsa, the Canadian immigrant success story and chairman of Fairfax Financial Holdings, was huddled in the offices of his Toronto law firm, Torys, trying to salvage the biggest bet of his career.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Ian Austen

articles.headline: Marrying Companies and Content
articles.snippet: The New York-based company Contently has developed a roster of writers and journalists for hire and a software application that helps companies tell their own stories.
articles.abstract: The New York-based company Contently has developed a roster of writers and journalists for hire and a software application that helps companies tell their own stories.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Contently, a hot little company, held a buzzy conference at the Bowery Hotel on a very of-the-moment topic.

articles.headline: Same Time, Same Channel? TV Woos Kids Who Can’t Wait
articles.snippet: In their efforts to attract children, television networks are starting to show programs online before they appear on old-fashioned TV.
articles.abstract: In their efforts to attract children, television networks are starting to show programs online before they appear on old-fashioned TV.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Eric Nelson’s 6-year-old daughter, Charlotte, and 10-year-old son, Asa, discover that they cannot rewind or fast-forward a TV show, they are perplexed — and their father is, too. It is hard to explain the limitations of live television to children who have grown up in an on-demand world.

articles.headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Airs Apology on Benghazi
articles.snippet: The CBS newsmagazine issued a rare retraction and apology for its report on an attack on Americans in Libya, saying it was misled by a source.
articles.abstract: The CBS newsmagazine issued a rare retraction and apology for its report on an attack on Americans in Libya, saying it was misled by a source.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lara Logan was scheduled to deliver a report on Sunday’s “60 Minutes” about disabled veterans who climb mountains. Instead, she appeared in front of the newsmagazine’s trademark black backdrop and issued an apology.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Health Website Tests a Tycoon and Tinkerer
articles.snippet: With no hands-on technology experience and a tight deadline, the entrepreneur Jeffrey D. Zients is leading the effort to fix HealthCare.gov.
articles.abstract: With no hands-on technology experience and a tight deadline, the entrepreneur Jeffrey D. Zients is leading the effort to fix HealthCare.gov.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeffrey D. Zients, a multimillionaire entrepreneur and management consultant, joined the Obama White House in 2009 with a mandate to streamline the federal bureaucracy. A year later, he issued a prescient warning.

articles.headline: Textbooks Reassess Kennedy, Putting Camelot Under Siege
articles.snippet: In the 50 years since his assassination, the image of John F. Kennedy has shifted from tragic hero to flawed leader.
articles.abstract: In the 50 years since his assassination, the image of John F. Kennedy has shifted from tragic hero to flawed leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The President John F. Kennedy students learn about today is not their grandparents’ J.F.K.

articles.headline: Postal Service to Make Sunday Deliveries for Amazon
articles.snippet: The plan covers the New York and Los Angeles metro areas and is expected to expand, and it offers the Postal Service a chance to take profitable business away from rivals.
articles.abstract: The plan covers the New York and Los Angeles metro areas and is expected to expand, and it offers the Postal Service a chance to take profitable business away from rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The cash-short United States Postal Service, which has failed to win congressional approval to stop delivering mail on Saturdays to save money, has struck a deal with the online retailer Amazon.com to deliver the company’s packages on Sundays — a first for both, with obvious advantages for each.

articles.headline: China’s One-Day Shopping Spree Sets Record in Online Sales
articles.snippet: Chinese consumers were taking to the Internet in record numbers for an annual 24-hour online sale that has ballooned into the world’s biggest e-commerce event.
articles.abstract: Chinese consumers were taking to the Internet in record numbers for an annual 24-hour online sale that has ballooned into the world’s biggest e-commerce event.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — Unmarried men across China used to spend Nov. 11 lamenting their single status with a drink. Now that unofficial holiday has become the world’s largest online shopping event.
articles.byline: By Shanshan Wang and Eric Pfanner

articles.headline: Struggle for Survival in Philippine City Shattered by Typhoon
articles.snippet: Destroyed buildings lined every road of Tacloban, the city hit hardest by the typhoon, and many streets were still so clogged with debris that they were barely discernible.
articles.abstract: Destroyed buildings lined every road of Tacloban, the city hit hardest by the typhoon, and many streets were still so clogged with debris that they were barely discernible.
articles.lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Decomposing bodies still lie along the roads, like a corpse in a pink, short-sleeve shirt and blue shorts facedown in a black, muddy puddle 100 yards from the airport. Just down the road is a church that was supposed to be an evacuation center but is littered with the bodies of those who drowned inside.

articles.headline: Amy Robach of ABC Says On-Air Mammogram Found Breast Cancer
articles.snippet: Amy Robach, an anchor on ABC’s “Good Morning America” who underwent a mammography on the program Oct. 1, said she will have a double mastectomy.
articles.abstract: Amy Robach, an anchor on ABC’s “Good Morning America” who underwent a mammography on the program Oct. 1, said she will have a double mastectomy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amy Robach, an anchor on ABC’s “Good Morning America,” had avoided her doctor’s recommendation for a mammogram screening for a year, when a producer for the show called at the end of September and asked her to consider undergoing a televised mammogram.
